004
005package edu.wpi.first.math.estimator;
006
007import edu.wpi.first.math.Drake;
008import edu.wpi.first.math.MathSharedStore;
009import edu.wpi.first.math.Matrix;
010import edu.wpi.first.math.Nat;
011import edu.wpi.first.math.Num;
012import edu.wpi.first.math.StateSpaceUtil;
013import edu.wpi.first.math.numbers.N1;
014import edu.wpi.first.math.system.Discretization;
015import edu.wpi.first.math.system.LinearSystem;
016
017/**
018 * A Kalman filter combines predictions from a model and measurements to give an estimate of the
019 * true system state. This is useful because many states cannot be measured directly as a result of
020 * sensor noise, or because the state is "hidden".
021 *
022 * <p>Kalman filters use a K gain matrix to determine whether to trust the model or measurements
023 * more. Kalman filter theory uses statistics to compute an optimal K gain which minimizes the sum
024 * of squares error in the state estimate. This K gain is used to correct the state estimate by some
025 * amount of the difference between the actual measurements and the measurements predicted by the
026 * model.
027 *
028 * <p>For more on the underlying math, read
029 * https://file.tavsys.net/control/controls-engineering-in-frc.pdf chapter 9 "Stochastic control
030 * theory".
031 */
032public class KalmanFilter<States extends Num, Inputs extends Num, Outputs extends Num> {
033  private final Nat<States> m_states;
034
035  private final LinearSystem<States, Inputs, Outputs> m_plant;
036
037  /** The steady-state Kalman gain matrix. */
038  private final Matrix<States, Outputs> m_K;
039
040  /** The state estimate. */
041  private Matrix<States, N1> m_xHat;
042
043  /**
044   * Constructs a state-space observer with the given plant.
045   *
046   * @param states A Nat representing the states of the system.
047   * @param outputs A Nat representing the outputs of the system.
048   * @param plant The plant used for the prediction step.
049   * @param stateStdDevs Standard deviations of model states.
050   * @param measurementStdDevs Standard deviations of measurements.
051   * @param dtSeconds Nominal discretization timestep.
052   * @throws IllegalArgumentException If the system is unobservable.
053   */
054  public KalmanFilter(
055      Nat<States> states,
056      Nat<Outputs> outputs,
057      LinearSystem<States, Inputs, Outputs> plant,
058      Matrix<States, N1> stateStdDevs,
059      Matrix<Outputs, N1> measurementStdDevs,
060      double dtSeconds) {
061    this.m_states = states;
062
063    this.m_plant = plant;
064
065    var contQ = StateSpaceUtil.makeCovarianceMatrix(states, stateStdDevs);
066    var contR = StateSpaceUtil.makeCovarianceMatrix(outputs, measurementStdDevs);
067
068    var pair = Discretization.discretizeAQTaylor(plant.getA(), contQ, dtSeconds);
069    var discA = pair.getFirst();
070    var discQ = pair.getSecond();
071
072    var discR = Discretization.discretizeR(contR, dtSeconds);
073
074    var C = plant.getC();
075
076    if (!StateSpaceUtil.isDetectable(discA, C)) {
077      var builder =
078          new StringBuilder("The system passed to the Kalman filter is unobservable!\n\nA =\n");
079      builder
080          .append(discA.getStorage().toString())
081          .append("\nC =\n")
082          .append(C.getStorage().toString())
083          .append('\n');
084
085      var msg = builder.toString();
086      MathSharedStore.reportError(msg, Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace());
087      throw new IllegalArgumentException(msg);
088    }
089
090    var P =
091        new Matrix<>(
092            Drake.discreteAlgebraicRiccatiEquation(discA.transpose(), C.transpose(), discQ, discR));
093
094    // S = CPCᵀ + R
095    var S = C.times(P).times(C.transpose()).plus(discR);
096
097    // We want to put K = PCᵀS⁻¹ into Ax = b form so we can solve it more
098    // efficiently.
099    //
100    // K = PCᵀS⁻¹
101    // KS = PCᵀ
102    // (KS)ᵀ = (PCᵀ)ᵀ
103    // SᵀKᵀ = CPᵀ
104    //
105    // The solution of Ax = b can be found via x = A.solve(b).
106    //
107    // Kᵀ = Sᵀ.solve(CPᵀ)
108    // K = (Sᵀ.solve(CPᵀ))ᵀ
109    m_K =
110        new Matrix<>(
111            S.transpose().getStorage().solve((C.times(P.transpose())).getStorage()).transpose());
112
113    reset();
114  }
115
116  public void reset() {
117    m_xHat = new Matrix<>(m_states, Nat.N1());
118  }
119
120  /**
121   * Returns the steady-state Kalman gain matrix K.
122   *
123   * @return The steady-state Kalman gain matrix K.
124   */
125  public Matrix<States, Outputs> getK() {
126    return m_K;
127  }
128
129  /**
130   * Returns an element of the steady-state Kalman gain matrix K.
131   *
132   * @param row Row of K.
133   * @param col Column of K.
134   * @return the element (i, j) of the steady-state Kalman gain matrix K.
135   */
136  public double getK(int row, int col) {
137    return m_K.get(row, col);
138  }
139
140  /**
141   * Set initial state estimate x-hat.
142   *
143   * @param xhat The state estimate x-hat.
144   */
145  public void setXhat(Matrix<States, N1> xhat) {
146    this.m_xHat = xhat;
147  }
148
149  /**
150   * Set an element of the initial state estimate x-hat.
151   *
152   * @param row Row of x-hat.
153   * @param value Value for element of x-hat.
154   */
155  public void setXhat(int row, double value) {
156    m_xHat.set(row, 0, value);
157  }
158
159  /**
160   * Returns the state estimate x-hat.
161   *
162   * @return The state estimate x-hat.
163   */
164  public Matrix<States, N1> getXhat() {
165    return m_xHat;
166  }
167
168  /**
169   * Returns an element of the state estimate x-hat.
170   *
171   * @param row Row of x-hat.
172   * @return the state estimate x-hat at i.
173   */
174  public double getXhat(int row) {
175    return m_xHat.get(row, 0);
176  }
177
178  /**
179   * Project the model into the future with a new control input u.
180   *
181   * @param u New control input from controller.
182   * @param dtSeconds Timestep for prediction.
183   */
184  public void predict(Matrix<Inputs, N1> u, double dtSeconds) {
185    this.m_xHat = m_plant.calculateX(m_xHat, u, dtSeconds);
186  }
187
188  /**
189   * Correct the state estimate x-hat using the measurements in y.
190   *
191   * @param u Same control input used in the last predict step.
192   * @param y Measurement vector.
193   */
194  public void correct(Matrix<Inputs, N1> u, Matrix<Outputs, N1> y) {
195    final var C = m_plant.getC();
196    final var D = m_plant.getD();
197    // x̂ₖ₊₁⁺ = x̂ₖ₊₁⁻ + K(y − (Cx̂ₖ₊₁⁻ + Duₖ₊₁))
198    m_xHat = m_xHat.plus(m_K.times(y.minus(C.times(m_xHat).plus(D.times(u)))));
199  }
200}
